Easy way to kill them: Get a container (lunchbox sized) and trap them inside using it. Trust me, it's easier to trap them than to swat one. Then, carefully (or quickly) close the container. You have to make sure it's closed, and the fly can't escape. Shake the container a lot and maybe bang it to stun or make the fly stressed. After, find a place with water (preferably a bucket with a lot of water) and submerge the container. Carefully open the container (maybe fully) and then, if you are scared of insects, run. Then, watch if the fly can fly. Pick it up, and make sure it can't. Grab some scissors, and stab/cut it. If you are a weirdo like me dissect it. I like starting to cut with the head, and feed it to ants.

Here's the best way to explain fly time relativity.  Look at your hand, move it from one place to another while counting to 1 second, then do the same motion but take 4 seconds to complete it.  That's how the fly perceives time, it processes information about 4 times faster than us, so everything appears to be moving 4 times slower to the fly, same as how you need a high speed camera to see what happened in slow motion, the human brain can't process images that quickly.
Pro tip: Because of this, you can kill a fly approaching it slowly. It will think that you are a static object because the slowness on top of slow motion makes you look still.

If you speed up your swatting, then problem solved. So how can we speed it up, like in an instant so we can succeed? I experimented and this is how it is. It's easy to swat a fly if you know how. You use both slow motion and instantly fast motion. When a fly lands, it always works. If you see a landed fly, prepare your swatter by flexing the lethal end of the swatter backwards with the other hand and slowly and fluently line the swatter up for an accurate direct hit (take your time to line it up perfect, cos as long as you are really slow the fly won't notice and you can take as long as you like). Then suddenly release (or flick) the swatter for an guaranteed strike. lol  You will get (at least) a 99% strike rate if you do that but if you just swat the fly normally you will get a 1% strike rate. And if you are missing flies it's most probably cos you haven't taken your time to line it up. Do not anticipate cos that causes much faster (slow) movement and the fly will notice. If you nudge the last inch in anticipation just before you release, it will almost certainly be a fail every time. lol It's all really slow until it flicks, that's the secret for a near 100% strike rate.

It may be hard to swat a fly, but to catch one is simple. If you have a butterfly net like I do, position the net just above the fly, moving very slowly. I'd say the distance between the edge of the net and the fly is roughly half an inch or so.

Normally, a fly will fly into the opposite direction it faces, so if a fly is facing towards the left, slam the net to the right. Due to the net's position at the opposite direction of the fly, it will most likely be caught. A butterfly net is ideal, but some can do it with fish nets.

One of the things you definitely don't want to do is to have your net's shadow touch the fly, as it will sense danger.

You also don't want to slam the edge of your net onto the fly like I have a few times, as that will definitely kill it. But hey, if you have a pet spider, reptile, amphibian, even a carnivorous plant, this is one of the ways to get it some food.

So technically, a fly doesn't experience time slower than humans, it just processes more information in the same second.
Flies tap into the Speed Force.

"We see things at a rate of 60 hz"

This is literally just not true lmao. Air force pilots can identify aircraft models that flash on the screen for 1/220th of a second or the equivalent of 220 hz.

If our eyes saw at 60 hz then pilots would miss the plane just by chance.

What our eyes really see is 60 hz as being lifelike, not as being the max frames we can see. If we saw at 60 hz and flashed an image at 1/200th of a second 10 times then at least one of those times you'd assume that your eyes wouldn't perceive the image but they do.

Eyes do not see at a frequency or a frame-rate. The stream of information is so fast that as far as we know it's constant.

If we really wanted to know the frame-rate of the eye we'd have to know how many times per second our eyes sent signals to the brain, and that number is much higher than 60.

Get your facts straight if you wanna call yourself the science channel :)
